raw_text:
Prince crowned 'top music earner'
 
 Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, beating artists such Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list.
 
 The singer banked $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global Re-Invention Tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year.
 
 "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album Musicology.
 
 Although she grossed more than Prince last year, Madonna remained in second place because of the "monumental" production costs of her tour. Heavy metal band Metallica's Madly in Anger with the World tour helped push their 2004 earnings up to $43.1m (£23.1m). They were ahead of Sir Elton John, who took fourth place and almost $42.7m (£23m) from performances including a debut on the Las Vegas Strip. Other seasoned performers in the list included Rod Stewart, whose sold-out shows and third volume of The Great American Songbook covers album helped net him £35m (£19m). The highest-ranking rap act in the list was 50 Cent, who at number 19 took $24m (£13m) to the bank.
llama3.2:1b:
Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004 with a reported $56.5 million from concerts, album, and publishing sales for his Musicology tour and album.

The top five earners were: 
1. Prince - $90.3 million (£48.5 million)
2. Madonna - $54.9 million (£29.5 million)
3. Metallica's Madly in Anger with the World tour - $43.1 million (£23.1 million) 
4. Sir Elton John - $42.7 million (£23 million)
5. Rod Stewart - £35 million (approximately $46 million USD)
llama3.2:3b: Prince earned $56.5m in 2004 from concerts and sales of his Musicology tour and album. He beat Madonna ($54.9m), Simon & Garfunkel ($24.9m), and Metallica ($43.1m).
gemma2:2b: Prince earned the most money in 2004 from music sales and concerts, totaling $56.5 million. He surpassed Madonna ($54.9 million) and Elton John ($42.7 million) on Rolling Stone's list.  Metallica was second, earning $43.1 million despite Madonna's higher gross revenue due to tour costs.

Simon & Garfunkel were in second place with their comeback tour, while Metallica and Sir Elton John were in third and fourth places respectively. A heavy metal band called Madly in Anger with the World tour helped push their earnings up to $43. 1m (£23. 1m), which exceeded that of Madonna's earnings by more than $40m (£23. 1m). Rap acts like 50 Cent also made a lot of money, earning $24m (£13m) from performances.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Prince topped Rolling Stone's annual music earnings list in 2004 with over $56 million from concerts and album sales, beating Madonna by more than $5 million despite her global tour costs. Metallica's Madly in Anger helped them advance further up the charts. Other notable performers included Simon & Garfunkel (10th), Rod Stewart, 50 Cent (19th).

Madonna was second with $54.9m from her Re-Invention Tour, while Simon & Garfunkel's comeback tour brought them $24.9m. Metallica placed fourth with $43.1m from their Madly in Anger with the World tour, ahead of Sir Elton John who took fourth place at $42.7m. Veteran performers like Rod Stewart (third) and Sir Elton John (fourth) also appeared on the list. Rap act 50 Cent ranked 19th, earning $24m.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Prince and Madonna's performance in Rolling Stone magazine in 2004. Let me read through it carefully.

First sentence: "Prince crowned 'top music earner'". So the summary should mention that Prince was crowned as the top music earner for that year.

Then, they mentioned he earned more than any other pop star back then. The text goes on to say Madonna and Elton John were in second place with their earnings mentioned at $54.9m and $29.5m respectively. Wait, no, actually, the next part says Madonna was in second with $54.9m and Garfunkel in 10th with $24.9m. But then it clarifies that Madonna still led because of production costs.

Next point: The tour sales for Prince were $56.5 million from concerts, albums, and publishing. Simon and Garfunkel were third place but earned $24.9m through their tours. Simon and Garfunkel also had a solo record, so they probably have more than just the album earnings.

Madonna's tour was a big success, earning $30.4 million in 2005 (the next year) because her tour took $90.3m in ticket sales. But she still led at second place because of tour expenses and press releases.

Metallica had their tour also in 2004, earning $43.1m ($23.1m at the time). They were third but led by an album that earned them $19m. Metallica's tour included a show on Las Vegas Strip where they played 50 Cent's 5th concert, which contributed $24m.

Other performers like Rod Stewart had high earnings from sold-out shows and their song collections. 50 Cent was at the top with $24m but 19th place overall due to lower sales elsewhere.

So putting this all together, I need to make sure each key point is included concisely. Focus on Prince's achievements, Madonna's position despite tour costs, the earnings from their tours and albums, Metallica's role, and other performers like Garfunkel and Stewart.
</think>

Prince was crowned the top music earner in 2004 for earning more than any other pop star. He earned $56.5 million from concerts, albums, and publishing, while Madonna stayed second at $30.4 million due to tour expenses. Simon and Garfunkel were third with $24.9m via tours. Metallica's tour raised earnings to $43.1m, surpassing fourth place by Elton John, who earned $23m from performances including a Las Vegas Strip show. Other performers included Rod Stewart and Garfunkel at 50 Cent (19th place) and Stewart with sold-out shows.

The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales and sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album Musicology, while Madonna remained in second place because of the "monumental" production costs of her tour. tinydolphin:1.1b: Prince, known for his hits "Purple Rain" and "Let's Go Crazy," has been crowned the top music earner in 2004 by the US magazine Rolling Stone. According to the report, he earned more than any other pop star that year with a reported total of $56.5 million from concerts, albums, and publishing sales. At number two on the list is Madonna, who earned $54.9 million from her 2004 tour. However, it was Simon and Garfunkel in third place, who were followed by veteran artists such as Simon and Garfunkel, who earned $24.9 million last year. The highest-ranked rap act in the list is 50 Cent, who took home an estimated $24 million from his performances in 2004.

The magazine notes that while Madonna made more than Prince last year, his Musicology tour was a big hit due to its massive production costs.
